name: Arcology
description: A future where marine ecosystems are governed primarily to preserve and restore intrinsic biodiversity value. Large-scale ocean wilderness areas are established as strictly protected no-take zones, allowing depleted ecosystems to recover autonomously. Human activities are excluded from ecologically critical areas, prioritizing species and habitat recovery over extractive use.
governance_model: Top-down regulatory governance with legally binding protection mandates. International treaties enforce high-seas marine protected area networks with permanent no-take designations and independent scientific oversight bodies.
key_policies: Designation of 50%+ of ocean area as strictly protected no-take marine reserves
Moratorium on deep-sea mining and bottom-trawling in all protected waters
Legally binding high-seas biodiversity treaty (BBNJ) with strong compliance mechanisms
Satellite-based vessel monitoring and AI-driven enforcement of exclusion zones
marine_examples: Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument (USA) — one of the world's largest fully protected marine areas covering 1.5 million km² with no extractive activities permitted
Ross Sea Marine Protected Area (CCAMLR) — the largest MPA in the Southern Ocean with a 1.55 million km² no-take general protection zone
Chagos Archipelago Marine Protected Area (UK) — a 640,000 km² no-take zone in the Indian Ocean demonstrating large-scale pelagic protection
trade_offs: Displacement of fishing communities from traditional grounds without adequate livelihood alternatives
Enforcement costs escalate with remoteness, requiring substantial long-term public investment
Potential conflict with food security goals in coastal developing nations dependent on marine protein
Risk of 'paper parks' if political will for enforcement diminishes over time
source: Durán et al. (2023); Pereira et al. (2020) Nature Futures Framework

name: Sharing through Sparing
nff_position: Nature for Nature – Nature for Society edge
description: A future balancing conservation ambitions with sustainable resource use through spatial zoning and science-based harvest limits. Dedicated marine reserves 'spare' biodiversity-rich areas from extraction, while adjacent zones are managed for optimal sustainable yield. The approach integrates ecosystem-based fisheries management with robust stock assessments.
governance_model: Science-advisory governance with integrated spatial planning. Regional fisheries management organizations and national agencies co-manage zones using adaptive harvest control rules informed by regular stock assessments and ecosystem modeling.
key_policies: Maximum Sustainable Yield (MSY) targets for all commercially exploited fish stocks with precautionary buffers
Marine Spatial Planning directives that designate core conservation zones, buffer zones, and sustainable-use areas
Transferable fishing quotas allocated through transparent, science-based Total Allowable Catch systems
Mandatory ecosystem impact assessments before licensing any new marine extractive activity
marine_examples: EU Common Fisheries Policy MSY mandate — legally requires all EU fish stocks to be managed at or below MSY by 2020, with multiannual plans for mixed fisheries
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park zoning (Australia) — a multi-use zoning system with 33% no-take areas alongside regulated fishing and tourism zones
Norwegian integrated ocean management plans — spatial plans for the Barents Sea balancing petroleum extraction, fisheries, and marine protection
trade_offs: MSY-based management may underestimate ecosystem interactions, leading to cascading effects on non-target species
Spatial zoning can create winners and losers among fishing fleets depending on historic access rights
High data requirements for stock assessments limit applicability in data-poor fisheries
Tension between short-term economic optimization and long-term ecological recovery timelines
source: Durán et al. (2023); Hilborn (2007) Managing fisheries is managing people

name: Optimizing Nature
description: A techno-optimist future where marine resources are maximized through innovation, precision aquaculture, and blue economy growth. Advanced monitoring, genetic improvement of farmed species, offshore renewable energy, and biotechnology drive efficient use of ocean resources. Nature is valued primarily for the services and economic returns it provides to society.
governance_model: Market-driven governance with strong public-private partnerships. Regulatory sandboxes enable rapid technology deployment while performance-based environmental standards replace prescriptive rules. Blue economy investment frameworks channel capital toward scalable marine enterprises.
key_policies: Blue Economy Growth Strategy with streamlined permitting for offshore aquaculture and renewable energy installations
Performance-based environmental standards for marine industries replacing prescriptive input controls
Public investment in marine biotechnology R&D, precision aquaculture genetics, and digital ocean monitoring
Payments for Ecosystem Services (PES) schemes monetizing carbon sequestration, coastal protection, and nutrient cycling
marine_examples: Norway's offshore aquaculture licenses — development permits for exposed ocean farming sites using submersible cage technology to scale salmon production beyond fjord carrying capacities
North Sea offshore wind farm clusters (EU) — large-scale renewable energy zones with co-location of mariculture, demonstrating multi-use ocean platforms
Singapore's vertical ocean farms and cellular aquaculture — high-tech urban seafood production combining recirculating systems with alternative protein development
trade_offs: Technology-intensive approaches may concentrate benefits among capital-rich actors, increasing inequality
Offshore aquaculture expansion risks pollution, disease transmission to wild stocks, and habitat disturbance
Overemphasis on economic optimization may neglect non-monetizable biodiversity and cultural values
Dependence on technological solutions creates vulnerability to infrastructure failure and cybersecurity risks
source: Durán et al. (2023); Bennett et al. (2021) Blue growth and blue justice

name: Innovative Commons
nff_position: Nature for Society – Nature as Culture edge
description: A future centered on participatory co-management and community-based governance of shared marine resources. Local fishing cooperatives, territorial use rights, and community-led ecological restoration projects ensure that both livelihoods and cultural ties to the sea are maintained. Innovation emerges from collective action rather than top-down regulation or market forces.
governance_model: Polycentric co-management with nested governance scales. Local resource user associations hold primary management authority over near-shore commons, coordinated through regional councils and supported by legal frameworks that recognize customary tenure and community-based monitoring.
key_policies: Territorial Use Rights in Fisheries (TURFs) granting exclusive access and management responsibility to local communities
Community-based marine area management with legally recognized local governance bodies and bylaws
Cooperative marketing and fair-trade certification systems linking small-scale producers to ethical supply chains
Participatory ecological restoration programs combining scientific expertise with local ecological knowledge
marine_examples: Chilean TURF-reserve system (AMERB) — over 700 community-managed benthic territories combining exclusive harvest rights with no-take reference areas for lolo, limpets, and kelp
Locally Managed Marine Areas in Fiji and the Pacific — networks of community-governed reef closures (tabu areas) integrated with periodic harvest and adaptive management
Japanese fishery cooperative associations (Gyokyō) — centuries-old community-based management of coastal fisheries with collective quota setting and habitat stewardship
trade_offs: Collective action challenges may lead to governance failures in heterogeneous or large-scale communities
TURFs can exclude newcomers and migrant fishers, creating equity issues around access rights
Community-based management may lack capacity for addressing cross-boundary or highly migratory species
Scaling up local innovations to regional or national levels requires institutional bridging that is often absent
source: Durán et al. (2023); Ostrom (1990) Governing the Commons; Gelcich et al. (2010)

name: Reciprocal Stewardship
description: A future where marine governance is rooted in cultural heritage, traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), and relational values between people and the sea. Small-scale artisanal fisheries are prioritized as carriers of intergenerational knowledge. Governance centers on reciprocity — communities care for marine ecosystems as culturally embedded stewards, and the sea in turn sustains cultural identity and wellbeing.
governance_model: Heritage-based governance grounded in customary marine tenure and Indigenous rights frameworks. Legal pluralism recognizes TEK alongside Western science in management decisions. Cultural seascape designations protect both biological and cultural heritage of marine areas.
key_policies: Formal recognition of Indigenous and community-conserved marine areas (ICCAs) in national legislation
Integration of Traditional Ecological Knowledge in stock assessments and environmental monitoring programs
Preferential access rights for small-scale artisanal fisheries in coastal zones as per FAO SSF Guidelines
UNESCO-style Cultural Seascape designations protecting biocultural marine heritage sites
marine_examples: Sasi laut marine tenure in Maluku, Indonesia — customary periodic reef closures governed by community elders that regulate harvest of trochus, sea cucumber, and reef fish
Māori customary fishing rights and rāhui (New Zealand) — legally recognized temporary closures and species bans under the Treaty of Waitangi settlement framework
Mediterranean small-scale fisheries (cofradías in Spain) — centuries-old fishing brotherhoods managing inshore resources through collective rules, seasonal closures, and shared ecological knowledge
trade_offs: TEK-based governance may struggle to address novel threats like ocean acidification or invasive species outside historical experience
Legal recognition of customary tenure can conflict with state sovereignty claims and existing regulatory frameworks
Risk of romanticizing traditional practices while overlooking internal community power asymmetries
Cultural preservation goals may resist necessary adaptation to climate-driven ecosystem shifts
source: Durán et al. (2023); Pereira et al. (2020); FAO (2015) Voluntary Guidelines for SSF

name: Dynamic Natures
nff_position: Nature as Culture – Nature for Nature edge
description: A future integrating biocultural conservation with ecosystem-based management, recognizing that biodiversity and cultural diversity are co-produced. Traditional fishing rights coexist with scientifically informed conservation measures. Dynamic, adaptive management responds to both ecological change and evolving cultural relationships with the sea, emphasizing resilience over static protection.
governance_model: Adaptive co-governance blending scientific monitoring with Indigenous and local knowledge systems. Management boundaries and rules shift in response to ecological and social signals. Rights-based approaches ensure both biodiversity outcomes and cultural continuity through flexible institutional arrangements.
key_policies: Adaptive ecosystem-based marine management with dynamic spatial closures responding to real-time ecological indicators
Biocultural heritage marine areas co-governed by Indigenous communities and conservation agencies
Rights-based fisheries management integrating customary tenure with science-informed catch limits
Climate adaptation corridors allowing mobile species protection zones to shift with changing ocean conditions
marine_examples: Great Bear Sea Indigenous Protected and Conserved Areas (Canada) — First Nations-led marine planning combining traditional governance with ecosystem-based management across 100,000+ km² of coastal waters

Australian Indigenous Rangers sea country programs — Indigenous land and sea management combining traditional burning, turtle monitoring, and modern surveillance to manage marine biodiversity on customary estates
Galician marisqueo a pie (Spain) — women-led intertidal shellfish harvesting cooperatives combining traditional knowledge of species biology with scientific monitoring and adaptive seasonal closures
trade_offs: Dynamic management requires sophisticated real-time monitoring infrastructure that may not be universally available
Integrating multiple knowledge systems creates epistemic tensions and requires skilled intercultural facilitation
Adaptive rules may create uncertainty for industries requiring stable long-term investment conditions
Balancing conservation strictness with cultural access rights demands ongoing negotiation and conflict resolution capacity
source: Durán et al. (2023); Sterling et al. (2017) Biocultural approaches to well-being; Ban et al. (2018)
